SC Urges 5 Changes
In Proposed Council

New Interim Body
May Set Precedents
The Temporary Advisory Council
(TAC) may have set two important
precedents at its Friday meeting,
but undergraduate members are not
very hopeful that the council will
make any significant changes in
University policy.
Chris Ohly, one of the four undergraduate representatives on the
19-member council, was designated
chairman of the TAC steering
committee. Ohly stated he hoped his
appointment would set a precedent
for future student appointments on
the council.
In addition, the 3-man steering
committee was composed of a grad
student, Bruce Neilson and Dr.
Francis Bretherton, Earth and
Planetary Science, besides Ohly.
The undergraduate, graduate,
faculty principle may also be
followed in the future, stated Ohly.
Nevertheless, two of the undergraduate members of the TAC
expressed doubts that the council
could open the way for more student
Power.
"I don't expect any radical
'changes in the structure of Hopkins

governance, coming out of the
TAC," said Ohly, "and if there were
some they probably won't be implemented."
Rick Posen, a junior, expressed a
similar view. He added that if the
TAC becomes something more than
temporary, he will resign. He added
he will not be part of a governance
system which isn't ratified by the
Homewood comniunity.
Both Ohly and Posen believe that
the governance proposals will be
defeated. In Ohly's words, "The
TAC will likely last at least until the
end of the academic year."
In its Saturday meeting, the
steering committee came up with a
possible agenda for the next TAC
meeting. That agenda could include
a discussion of the setting up of a
committee on government financing, including Department of
Defense and NASA grants as well as
other federal giants.
The TAC is serving as an interim
advisory council until the formal
governance system is submitted for
a vote next month.

The Student Council has backed
the Governance Committee's
proposed Arts and Sciences
Representative Council (ASRC), but
in a letter to committee chairman
Dean Strider it urged five changes,
including giving the ASRC delegated
authority.
On Nov. 16 Homewood will vote on
Committee's
Governance
th
proposals.
SC President Mack Lee predicted
that the proposal of giving the ASRC
delegated rather than de facto
authority will be turned down, but
that the other four will be accepted.
The SC letter maintained that the
Dean should be responsible for
providing such information to the
ASRC as it needs in order to decide
policy.
The Council also stated that the
Committee on Instruction should not
be established. According to the SC,
the activities for which this committee was designed could be
handled by the Committee on Undergraduate Studies and the
Graduate Board.
The third SC proposal was that

individual departments be required
to implement at least one of the
proposed mechanisms for student
power in departmental decisionmaking. Ideally, they said this
would entail the establishment of
student-faculty conferences in all
departments.
The SC also opposed the ammending process because the
suggested system would put more
value on certain groups which are
numerical minorities. Furthermore,
they assert since two thirds of the
ASRC must vote for an amendment
to appear before the public, the Dean
should not be granted the power to
decide if it should be ratified.
The fifth SC proposal is that
standing committee members of the
ASRC should only be nominated by
their respective organizations.
The Dean, acting as a mediary,
must insure that the proposals of the
ASRC are administered on a daily
basis. The SC stresses that the
students and faculty of Homewood
must accept the responsibilitees of
governing themselves rather than
relying on paid administrators

Hopkins vs. HEW
The University, it seems, is more interested in
avoiding a cut-off in Federal funds than it is in ending
job discrimination. HEW rejected two job rights plans,
or Affirmative Action Programs, because the
University set goals too low and failed to provide enough
data on hiring policies. Apparently, the University
thought that vague promises might placate the Office of
Civil Rights as efficiently as they do students.
But unlike students, the government has power, and
so it demanded hard facts and concrete objectives. The
University, even after one rejection, set percentage
goals that were too low for a city that is 50 per cent
black. And it refused to set any objectives at all for
black faculty, because, among other dubious reasons,
recruiting is a long-term process. Yet while the Administration insists it is actively seeking black
professors, the sour facts remain: there are only 19
blacks among the 1280 faculty hired by Hopkins. The
much-stated desire to preserve academic standards
seems more like a ploy to preserve white sensibilities.
The third report, submitted this June, had enough
data and high enough goals to apease HEW. But if the
University's record on certain anti-bias steps is any
indication, even Hopkins' not-so-lofty goals will go
unrealized. For example, the vital overview committee
of the program met only once. And one black administrator was never even told about the plan.
Students, as usual, were never informed about the
Affirmative Action Programs. The University commitment to end job discrimination is not just, as one
official said, "an internal administrative matter." It
should be a concern of all members of the University,
and only a vigilant and aware Hopkins community will
ensure that the administration ends job bias.

Minimester Flop
Envisioned as a period of educational innovation, the
upcoming minimester appears to be headed for its
second straight failure.
Only five departments have met to plan minimester
programs. True, many departments are making sure
that their grad students have lots of activities to choose
from during the intersession but, true to Hopkins
tradition, they would rather not be bothered with the
undergraduates. Some departments have graciously
allowed their own individual students and faculty to plan
minimester courses and independent research projects.
To sit down and plan a program is apparently too much
to ask.
As the heart of administrative and academic power, it
should be the departments' task to organize their offerings for the minimester. The resources of the city as
well as those of the campus are at the disposal of any
imaginative mind. Dr. Hunt's trip to Death Valley and
the Psychology Department seminars during last year's
minimester are examples of different ways in which the
period can be used for educational innovation.
If departments refuse to act on their own, a little
prodding from the administration and students might
get them moving. Last year Dean Swanson evidently
thought that the program was worth only a memo to the
faculty, which was duly ignored. This year Swanson will
place minimester planning in the hands of a subcommittee of a committee, the traditional Hopkins
graveyard for any good idea. The program deserves far
more attention and concern.

Hopkins vs. HEW
The University, it seems, is more interested in
avoiding a cut-off in Federal funds than it is in ending
job discrimination. HEW rejected two job rights plans,
or Affirmative Action Programs, because the
University set goals too low and failed to provide enough
data on hiring policies. Apparently, the University
thought that vague promises might placate the Office of
Civil Rights as efficiently as they do students.
But unlike students, the government has power, and
so it demanded hard facts and concrete objectives. The
University, even after one rejection, set percentage
goals that were too low for a city that is 50 per cent
black. And it refused to set any objectives at all for
black faculty, because, among other dubious reasons,
recruiting is a long-term process. Yet while the Administration insists it is actively seeking black
professors, the sour facts remain: there are only 19
blacks among the 1280 faculty hired by Hopkins. The
much-stated desire to preserve academic standards
seems more like a ploy to preserve white sensibilities.
The third report, submitted this June, had enough
data and high enough goals to apease HEW. But if the
University's record on certain anti-bias steps is any
indication, even Hopkins' not-so-lofty goals will go
unrealized. For example, the vital overview committee
of the program met only once. And one black administrator was never even told about the plan.
Students, as usual, were never informed about the
Affirmative Action Programs. The University commitment to end job discrimination is not just, as one
official said, "an internal administrative matter." It
should be a concern of all members of the University,
and only a vigilant and aware Hopkins community will
ensure that the administration ends job bias.

that their grad students have lots of activities to choose
from during the intersession but, true to Hopkins
tradition, they would rather not be bothered with the
undergraduates. Some departments have graciously
allowed their own individual students and faculty to plan
minimester courses and independent research projects.

get them moving. Last year Dean Swanson evidently
thought that the program was worth only a memo to the
faculty, which was duly ignored. This year Swanson will

graveyard for any good idea. The program deserves far
